title: Who beat Twist and Pulse in 2010 as they win BGT The Champions?
text:
Twist and Pulse were victorious in the Britain’s Got Talent final this weekend (Picture: Youtube/BGT)

Dance duo Twist and Pule won Britain’s Got Talent: The Champions over the weekend in a final that divided viewers.

Despite fan favourite Paul Potts’ making a shock exit earlier in the competition and BGT legend Susan Boyle not competing again this year, UK acts still managed to claim both first and second place in the TV competition, with Twist and Pulse taking the crown and father-son comedy/dance act Stavros Flatley coming in second.

After taking the winners’ title in the close competition, Twist and Pulse’s Ashley Glazebrook said: ‘Things like this don’t happen to me and my best friend Glen… this means the world to us.’

But who beat Twist and Pulse back in 2010 when they first appeared on Britain’s Got Talent?

Who won Britain’s Got Talent in 2010?

London-born dancers Twist and Pulse, aka Ashley Glazebrook and Glen Murphy, made it through to the finals when they first appeared on Britain’s Got Talent in 2010.

After their very first audition, Ant and Dec said of the talented mates: ‘With their bright outfits and body popping moves, they reminded us of ourselves back in our PJ & Duncan days with one small difference, they could actually dance, and we couldn’t.’

The best friends, whose first act together before appearing on the show was called Cheeky Boiz, where they created online ‘streetomedy’ (street/comedy) videos, ended up finishing in second place behind Spelbound.

The winners of BGT in 2010, Spelbound, are a gymnastic troupe from the UK. They went on to perform at the Olympics after winning £100,000 on the show.

Like their former BGT 2010 finalists, following their rise to fame on the show Twist and Pulse also performed at the Olympics, going on to present and perform at every date of the 70-day Olympic Torch Relay Tour in 2012.

The dancing duo also appeared on TV shows including Magic Numbers, Celebrity Juice, CBBC’s The Slammer, ITV’s Tenable and BBC One’s Let’s Dance for Comic Relief with Lee Nelson.

In 2013, they were watched by over 400 million people, performing the world’s biggest street dance show on CCTV News.

Twist & Pulse are appearing on This Morning today, which airs at 10.30am on ITV.
